description: Erection of 1 x 2 bed and 1 x 3 bed dwelling houses following the demolition of the existing garages
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of thePlanning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development hereby approved shall be carried out in accordance with details and samples for all facing materialswhich shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority before any works above ground levelare commenced. The development shall then be built in accordance with these approved samples and completed prior tooccupation.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (DesignRequirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall not commence until a Sustainable Drainage Strategy and associated detaileddesign, management and maintenance plan of surface water drainage for the site using SUDs methods has beensubmitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved drainage system shall be implementedin accordance with the approved Sustainable Drainage Strategy prior to the first occupation of the development andmaintained thereafter for the lifetime of the development.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequentdesign of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to prevent the increased risk of flooding byensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build ofthe proposed development, in accordance with Policies 5.2 and 5.3 of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 of theCore Strategy Adopted (2012).

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction method statement has beensubmitted to and been approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adheredto throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from developmentworks.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course ofdevelopment.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors.(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.The demolition and construction of the development shall be carried out in accordance with the construction methodstatement so agreed.No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction management plan or constructionmethod statement has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approvedplan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take placeat the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residentialoccupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (DesignRequirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the commencement of work above the damp proof course level of the development hereby approved, a detailedacoustic report on the existing noise climate at the development site has been submitted to and been approved in writingby the local planning authority. The report shall include a scheme of noise insulation measures for the hereby approved dwelling. The noise insulation measures shall be designed to achieve noise insulation to a standard that nuisance will notbe caused to the occupiers of the hereby approved dwelling by noise from the following:- train tracks to the north of theapplication site.The noise assessment shall be carried out by a suitably qualified acoustic consultant/engineer and shall take into account the provisions of BS 8233: 2014 Guidance on sound insulation and noise reduction for buildings. The approved scheme shall be implemented prior to the commencement of the use and be permanently maintained thereafter.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of residential occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012. The details are needed prior to the start of work so that any mitigatingmeasures can be incorporated into the build.

No work relating to the development hereby approved, including works of demolition or preparation prior to buildingoperations, shall take place other than between the hours of 08:00 and 18:00 Monday to Friday and 08:00 to 13:00Saturdays and at no time on Sundays or Bank or National Holidays.Reason: To protect the occupiers of neighbouring properties from noise and disturbance outside the permitted hoursduring the construction period, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments includingHouse Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development or other operations shall take place except in complete accordance with the approved document titled12170_R01b_Arboricultural Impact Assessment and Method Statement received by the local planning authority on 14thFebruary 2020 (hereinafter referred to as the Approved Scheme).a. No operations shall commence on site in connection with development hereby approved until the tree protection worksrequired by the Approved Scheme are in place on site.b. No excavations for services, storage of materials or machinery, parking of vehicles, deposit or excavation of soil orrubble, lighting of fires or disposal of liquids shall take place within an area designated as being fenced off orotherwise protected in the Approved Scheme.c. The fencing or other works which are part of the Approved Scheme shall not be moved or removed, temporarily orotherwise, until all works including external works have been completed and all equipment, machinery and surplusmaterials removed from the site, unless the prior approval in writing of the local planning authority has first beensought and obtained.Reason: To prevent unnecessary damage occurring to the trees during building operations, thereby safeguarding thevisual amenities of the site in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments includingHouse Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved, a scheme of ecological enhancement shall have beensubmitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The scheme shall include details of the features to beenhanced, recreated and managed for species of local importance both in the course of development and in the future.The scheme shall be carried out prior to the occupation of any part of the development or in accordance with aprogramme agreed in writing with the local planning authority.Reason: To safeguard and protect the sites biodiversity and nature conservation value in accordance with Policy DM6(Biodiversity) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted, a landscaping scheme, including where applicable theretention of the existing trees, shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. Theapproved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and thetree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the local planningauthority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and thearea shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the local planning authority shall be satisfied as to the details ofthe development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including HouseExtensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted the front elevation windows serving the ensuite ineach of the proposed dwellings as shown on the approved drawings shall be constructed so that no part of the frameworkless than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in,obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shallbe non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity tolevel 3.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance withPolicy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core StrategyAdopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the approved development, a plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the localplanning authority indicating the positions, design, materials and type of all gates, boundary treatment, fences and meansof enclosures to be erected. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved plan before thebuilding is occupied.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interest of visual amenity, inaccordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

The vehicle parking space shown on the approved plans shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior tothe first occupation of development and shall thereafter be retained for this use at all times.Reason: To ensure adequate on-site parking provision in the interests of highway safety, convenience and amenity, inaccordance with CS 7 (Managing Vehicle Use) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The car parking shown upon the approved drawings shall be provided with a hard-bound dust free surface,adequately drained before the development to which it relates is occupied and, thereafter, it shall be kept free fromobstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purposes otherthan the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion ofsurrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developmentsincluding House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012

The residential units hereby approved shall not be occupied until the development has been built in accordance withthe requirements of Category 2 of the Building Regulations document titled 'Approved Document M - Access to and use ofbuildings'. Reason: In the interest of inclusive design and accessibility in accordance with Policy 3.8 of the London Plan.

Within 3 months of first occupation, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development herebypermitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent toCode for Sustainable Homes Level 4.Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 andWAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide". Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part Lregulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day must be submitted to the local planning authority, unless otherwiseagreed in writing.Reason: In order to ensure that all development is designed and built to make the most efficient use of resources, reduceits lifecycle impact on the environment and contributes to climate change mitigation and adaptation in accordance withPolicy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order2015 (or any Order revoking and/or re-enacting that Order) no extension or enlargement (including additions to roofs)shall be made to the dwellinghouse(s) hereby permitted, or any detached building erected, without the express permissionin writing of the Council.Reason: To safeguard the privacy and amenity of adjoining occupiers, maintain adequate amenity space and safeguardthe cohesive appearance of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for NewDevelopments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved, details of the cycle store  facilities including finishesand dimensions shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved details shall be made available for use prior to the first occupation of the development and shall thereafter be retained for this use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycle store facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 of the CoreStrategy Adopted (2012).

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved, a waste and recycling management strategy that includesthe stipulation that future occupants would be responsible for transporting waste and recycling to the kerbside of LovelaceGardens for Council collection shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The plan shallthereafter be adhered to at all times for the lifetime of the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate refuse and recycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 of the CoreStrategy Adopted (2012).

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted. The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks to install two rooflights to the rear roof slope. The Council agrees that the amendments to which this decision letter relates are sufficiently minor in terms of their scale and impact (both individually and cumulatively) in planning terms, having regard to the overall scope of the previously approved development, so as to constitute a non-material amendment to the original planning permission/consent. This letter does not constitute a new planning permission. The development should be built in full accordance with the original planning permission except where amended by this decision.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

The site comprises semi-detached dwelling on Cambridge Avenue.6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment:  While the proposed two storey side extension would include a flat roof which should generally be avoided, it would be consistent with the existing flat roof element of the first floor, in respect of the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD. The rear extension would also generally follow the guidelines set out in the Residential Design SPD, in regards to the proposed height(3m) and depth(3.5m).Officers note that the conversion of the garage into habitable space with alterations to fenestration would slightly alter the appearance of the front elevation, however, it would not significantly detract from the wider streetscene or the host dwelling.Therefore, officers consider that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development and would be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 and 25 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: Whilst the existing garage would safely accommodate on-site car parking and would comply with the space parameters required by the Sustainable Transport SPD, 2013. Officers consider that the omission of the garage would not result in the loss of off-street car parking provision on site, as the hardstanding to the front of the property would provide adequate space for car parking. However, the loss of the garage would remove the potential for the safe storage of cycles, as such, it is reasonable to impose a condition requiring details of cycle parking to be submitted and approved.Therefore, overall, the proposal is considered not to have an adverse impact on car parking provision, traffic congestion or highway safety, in compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: Although the applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy and proposed plans which include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point, it does not sufficiently address the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Additionally, officers note that the flat roof form would not respect the symmetry of the host dwelling's pitched roof. However, the proposal would not be visible from the streetscene or wider area and will be constructed with similar materials to those used for the host dwelling. Whilst the front/side first-floor extension would be visible from the street, it would be reasonably small in scale and would appear proportionate and subordinateÂ to the host dwelling. The proposal would also be of matching materials to those used in the construction of the host dwelling.Overall, officers consider that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development and would be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The existing garage would not safely accommodate on-site car parking by failing to comply with the space parameters required by the Sustainable Transport SPD, 2013. Officers consider that the omission of the garage would not result in the loss of off-street car parking provision on site, as the hardstanding to the front of the property would provide adequate space for car parking. However, the loss of the garage would remove the potential for the safe storage of cycles, as such, it is reasonable to impose a condition requiring details of cycle parking to be submitted and approved.Therefore, overall, the proposal is considered not to have an adverse impact on car parking provision, traffic congestion or highway safety, in compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The application site comprises pavement outside 126 Tolworth Rise and is located within Tolworth District Centre Inset Area and Tolworth Key Area of Change Consultations21 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.TFL response:- The site forms part of the Transport For London Road Network (TLRN) of which TfL is the highway authority.The proposal  has not demonstrated how the proposal would support the 10 Healthy Streets indicators in line with London Plan Policy T2(d) - The existing units proposed for removal have static non-illuminated posters. This differs from the two adverts proposed which are larger, taller, illuminated and will face oncoming traffic in both directions on a busy road.-The proposed unit will be located in close proximity to the Tolworth Roundabout and a signalised pedestrian crossing. TfL has concerns that the unit may pose a potential distraction for drivers.-The 4 for 1 removal/replacement principle underpins the overall Street Hub roll-out programme, and without the removal of four old kiosks for every new one installed, TfL would object to applications on the grounds of street clutter and impact on amenity and safety terms. -There is already an existing phone box across the road of the proposed site and another approximately 100 metres away north on the A240 Tolworth Broadway. These can be used in the event that the public need to make calls rather than use their mobile. The need for this many phone kiosks in this area is considered unnecessary.-There are no plans provided regarding the installation of the Street Hub unit and where vehicles will park/stop during its installation. TfL therefore requests more detail prior to determination.RBK Environmental Health Officer - No objectionRBK Transport Officer - No comment receivedThe key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on public safetyDesign When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) states that development proposals should avoid locating advertisements and signs where they will be visually intrusive and likely to result in an adverse effect on the character and visual amenities of the local and wider area.Officer Comment: The proposed communication hub with internally lit advertisement LCD by virtue of its siting in a prominent position in the public highway and tall appearance would lead to an incongruous addition to the streetscene which would be visually intrusive creating visual street clutter that would detract from the character and appearance of the area.Public SafetyPolicy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy seeks to ensure that new development has regard to local traffic conditions and does not contribute to congestion, on street car parking pressure, or compromise pedestrian or highway safety. Officer Comment: While the proposed unit would be set in 3m from Tolworth Broadway, TfL has raised concerns about the close proximity of the unit to the Tolworth Roundabout and a signalised pedestrian crossing. Given the siting of the unit in this location, along with static imaging, it is considered that the unit may pose a potential distraction at a point where driver concentration is critical, thus endangering the safety of those using the crossing and navigating the roundabout, which has multiple lanes and traffic lightsIn conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.6x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the development on flooding; and,- Fire Safety.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed ground floor extension would extend 4.0 metres, into the rear garden. Overall, it is considered that the proposed extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the host property, or surrounding area.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: There is an existing ground floor extension to the rear of No. 146 Somerset Avenue and the proposed rear extension would be partly hidden by the detached shed/garage to the rear of No.150. It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of either neighbouring properties at No. 146 at No. 150 Somerset Avenue, by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts.Officer Comment: A Flood Risk Form has not been submitted by the applicant. However, appropriate mitigation measures can be introduced as part of the proposed development, in accordance with Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012) and a standard flood risk prevention condition is recommended.Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalDemolition of existing conservatory and erection of single-storey rear extensionPlanning History00/07393/FUL- Formation of a dormer in the rear of the roof and the erection of a second-floor rear extension - refused on 23/01/200104/16602/FUL - Erection of a single storey rear extension-refused on 29/12/2004..05/16077/FUL - Erection of rear conservatory- GRANTED 05.04.2005Consultation8x Neighbouring properties have been notified and one representations has been received, which highlights the following issues:--Extractor blowing fumes directly onto the neighbouring property.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire Safety Assessment.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed development is to the rear of the property. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment:  Given that the rear extension would abut the shared boundary with the adjoining property at no. 211 Raeburn Avenue and it would extend to a depth of 5.7 metres, which is further in depth than is recommended, officers consider that the proposed development would cause an unacceptable overbearing impact, increase in the sense of enclosure and loss of outlook to the adjoining property at no. 211 Raeburn Avenue. In terms of loss of daylight, the agent for this application has stated that nearest window to no.213 is to a dining room. However, this "is secondary source of light", as there is one more window and a glazed door. The agent has also provided additional floorplans, showing the internal ground floor layout of no. 211 Raeburn Avenue. Officers, therefore conclude that there would be no significant loss of daylight caused to no. 211 Raeburn Avenue, as a result of the proposed development.In terms of direct sunlight, the ground floor extension proposed, would be on the North side of the adjoining property at no. 211 Raeburn Avenue. As a result of the location of the proposed extension, there would be no significant loss of direct sunlight caused to the adjoining property at no. 211 Raeburn Avenue. There is an existing conservatory extension to the rear of the host property and the proposed extension would only project to a depth of 4.5 metres closest to the boundary with no. 215 Raeburn Avenue and would be set away from no.215. Taking these factors into account, there would be no significant overbearing impact, increase in the sense of enclosure, loss of outlook loss of daylight or direct sunlight caused to this adjoining property.Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through condition.By reason of its scale and depth, the proposed single storey rear extension, would adversely impact the amenities of the neighbouring property at no. 211 Raeburn Avenue, by reason of an unacceptable overbearing impact, increase in the sense of enclosure and loss of outlook to the adjoining property at no. 211 Raeburn Avenue. The proposal is therefore contrary to policies D3 of the London Plan 2021, policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The National Planning Practice Guidance notes that there is no statutory definition of "non material" and it is dependent on the context of the overall scheme. Under government guidance the local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, what may be non-material in one context may be material in another. The definition of non-material is the responsibility of each local planning authority to determine. The judgement on "materiality" in any particular case is one of fact and degree, also taking into account the likely impacts of the amendment. Materiality is considered against the development as a whole, not just a part of it.The proposal is for changes to the details and the number of cycle racking facilities, which are materially different from the original condition and the discharged details.General Comments: It is noted that only very limited survey data has been provided to demonstrate  the use of the cycle store.It is considered that should you wish to pursue a Section 73 application for the proposed changes, full consideration should also  be given to facilities that would promote the use of cycles and other sustainable transport initiatives, including the provision of  pool cycles/ a shared cycle scheme,  including electric cycles, which should be made available for the use of all residents of the development, including any seasonal residents, and promoted within the travel plan.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey detached dwellinghouse located on Sheephouse Way. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Planning HistoryNo relevant planning history. Consultations14 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on highways. The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application partly proposes the construction of a single storey front extension to facilitate a porch. This extension would not dominate the front elevation of the property, and would appear as an original feature. The application proposes the construction of a two-storey side extension. This extension would be set back from the front elevation of the property and set down from the ridgeline of the property sufficiently. Furthermore, the extension would not exceed 50% of the width of the original dwellinghouse. Officers note that the proposed extension would not be set in from the boundary by at least 1 metre, instead the development would be set in by approximately 0.5 metres. Whilst not ideal, Officers consider that the proposed side extension would appear proportionate and subordinate to the dwellinghouse, and would therefore have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the dwelling and surrounding area. Finally the application proposes the construction of a single storey rear extension. This extension would measure a maximum of approximately 4.2 metres in depth from the rear wall of the dwellinghouse, and would have a flat roof measuring approximately 3 metres in height. The application also proposes two lantern lights on the roof of this extension, which would exceed the 3 metres in height. Whilst the proposed extension would exceed the recommended maximum depth as outlined by the Residential Design SPD, Officers consider that the proposed extension would appear proportionate and subordinate to the dwellinghouse. Therefore Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse or area. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: The principal properties to consider in relation to amenity are No. 51 and No. 55 Sheephouse Way. In relation to No. 51 Sheephouse Way, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of this neighbouring property by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In relation to No. 55 Sheephouse Way, regarding sunlight and an overbearing appearance, the primary concern would be the proposed two storey side extension. This neighbouring property benefits from a window at ground floor level, however this appears to facilitate a hallway, which is not considered a habitable room. As the proposed side extension is only set in from the shared boundary by approximately 0.5 metres with this neighbouring property, the proposed development may lead to an overbearing appearance and loss of sunlight to this window. However, given the urban context of the site and the nature of the space served by the windows, Officers consider the proposed development to have an acceptable impact on the neighbouring property in terms of sunlight and an overbearing appearance. In relation to privacy, the application proposes one window at first floor level facing the neighbouring property at No. 51 Sheephouse Way. In the event of an approval, Officers consider it appropriate to attach a condition to the permission to ensure that the proposed window would be installed as obscure glazed and retained thereafter. Policy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy DM10 supports this stance.Officers Comments: The application proposes the loss of an existing garage. To accommodate modern vehicles, proposed new garages should meet the required dimensions as recommended by Appendix 5 of the Sustainable Transport SPD, measuring 3 metres in width and 5.3 metres in depth internally. The existing garage would not meet the minimum required internal garage dimensions for one vehicle, and therefore the removal of this garage would not impact the parking provision on site.London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling within flood zone 2.ProposalErection of single story rear extensionConsultationSix neigbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- The impact of the development on Flood Risk; and,- The impact of the development on Fire Safety.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Policy Guidance 33 (Single Storey Rear Extensions) states that single storey rear extensions should be designed so that they appear proportionate and subordinate to the host building. In all cases, the following guidance applies:- If the neighbouring house is set at a lower level, the depth of the extension should be reduced.- If the neighbouring property has a different rear building line, then the depth of the extension could be increased.- In all cases, at least 50% of the rear garden should remain.- Extensions should generally not exceed 3m to 3.5m in depth.- Extensions with a flat roof should not exceed 3m in height.The proposed rear extension would be approximately 3.1m in height with a flat roof and 4.5m in depth. It is noted that the proposed height is not strictly in compliance with the above guidance,  however, officers feel this alone would not warrant refusal Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  The principal properties to be considered in relation to neighbouring amenity are No. 37 and No. 41 Thornhill Road. Officers note that No. 41 Thornhill Road already benefits from a 4.5m rear extension. With regards to No. 37 Thornhill Road, due to the separation distance and existing boundary treatment it is not considered the proposed extension would not result in loss of daylight or privacy. Overall, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. The Flood Risk Form submitted by the applicant indicates that floor levels within the proposed development would be set no lower than the main dwelling and appropriate mitigation measures would be implemented as part of the proposed development which are considered acceptable and in accordance with Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
